title: The Truth about the CLT
question_text:
Which of the statements is true?

I. The Central Limit Theorem states that the standard deviation of the sampling distribution will be larger when the sample size is larger.
II. The distribution of the weights of all guinea pigs is nearly normal. The Central Limit Theorem assures us that the means from samples of size $7$ will also be nearly normal.
III. The Central Limit Theorem states that the larger the sample size, the more normal the shape of the population distribution.

choices.text: None of the statements is true.

solution:
Statement I is false. Larger sample sizes yield smaller standard deviations in sampling distributions. The Central Limit Theorem gives us information about the sampling distribution, as it approaches a normal distribution with increasing sample size.

Statement II is false. When the population distribution is nearly normal, the sampling distributions will always be nearly normal - no need for the CLT.

Statement III is false. The Central Limit Theorem states that the larger the sample size, the more normal the shape of the sampling distribution. The shape of the population distribution cannot be changed.
